findings.title: Trusted forwarder can take over the WalletFactory contract
findings.description: The trusted forwarder contract can call the upgrade function on the `WalletFactory` contract by submitting the owner address as the value of `msg.sender`, allowing it to control all owner-specific operations.

findings.title: Lack of contract existence check on StaticHyVM
findings.description: The `StaticHyVM` contract does not perform a contract existence check before making a delegatecall, which can lead to incorrect behavior if the called contract is nonexistent.

findings.title: Address aliasing on optimistic rollups is not considered
findings.description: The system does not consider address aliasing on optimistic rollups.

findings.title: Undocumented expectations for state-changing operations in HyVM
findings.description: The `HyVM` contract still allows certain state-changing operations after PR #1 removed some of them, but it's unclear whether they should be allowed.

findings.title: Invalid EVM versions possible in multi-chain deployment
findings.description: The HyVM and Tetris contracts contain Solidity pragmas that constrain the compiler’s version to 0.8.16 or above. However, if these contracts were to be compiled with Solidity 0.8.20 and deployed to a chain that has not implemented EIP-3855, the contracts would fail to deploy because Solidity 0.8.20 would default to the “Shanghai” EVM version.

findings.title: executeCall will always revert when sending native tokens
findings.description: In NestedWallet.sol, executeCall and executeMultiCall payable functions use OpenZeppelin's Address.functionCallWithValue function to make an arbitrary call to the target address, but _wrapNativeToken is called before, which deposits msg.value worth of native tokens into the WETH contract, causing the transaction to revert with 'Address: insufficient balance for call' error.
